sub_title: Public-Private Partnerships Specialist & Systems Thinker  |  Infrastructure • Climate Finance • Water Security | Regenerative Economy | Salzburg Global Seminar Fellow
summary:
PPP and infrastructure systems specialist and systems thinker. With 18 years of experience in Public-Private Partnerships, she is a multi-disciplinary leader who has advised governments on how to catalyze private sector investments in infrastructure, water and climate adaptation in Asia, Latin America, Europe, and Africa. 

She applies economics of infrastructure and systems engineering to analyze the institutional framework for infrastructure finance, facilitate complex multi-party financing and catalyze innovative partnerships.
Monica is passionately committed to making water security and adaptation to climate change financially feasible for developing countries. 

A thought leader in climate finance, water security, Nature-based Solutions and resilient infrastructure, Monica’s focus is working with government and business leaders to rethink investment origination processes and drive a paradigm shift in infrastructure planning. A shift from siloed, project-based and budget dictated thinking towards an integrated, mission-driven and systemic way of planning investments at the right scale, led by local stakeholders and embracing the role of ecosystems as critical infrastructure networks that enable all our economic activities and value chains. 

She has initiated and successfully implemented pioneering programs in resilient infrastructure, climate adaptation and water security for the European Commission, the Netherlands government, the Green Climate Fund, the Organization of American States, Microsoft and multilateral development banks. 

She is Chair of the Water and Natural Infrastructure Chapter of WAPPP, member of the steering committee of the Coalition for Private Investment in Conservation (CPIC), member of the WEF Infrastructure 4.0 Initiative, and the OECD Roundtable on Financing Water. She is an independent expert member of the NOW partners community of practice. 

Expert on ESG investing and the management of climate physical and transition risks. Developed solutions for corporates to manage water and climate risks including handbook on the implementation of Nature-based Solutions.

Monica’s years of diverse experience around the world contribute to her exceptional ability to identify linkages, distil complex data, conceptualize solutions for ill-defined problems in real-world settings, apply innovative thinking, promote a learning culture and manage change.  Previously she worked as PPP specialist for the Netherlands water institute Deltares and as advisor to the Netherlands government International Water Affairs team.

projects.title: Governance for Smartening Public Private Partnerships
projects.description:
Public-private partnerships have become business as usual in the Dutch and International practice of Public Administration. PPPs are used to engage in long term cooperation on the fields of infrastructure, road provision and urban restructuring, but also on fields such as health care, water management or energy.In this research program various forms of public-private (and societal) partnerships are studied. The focus is on innovative role division between the actors and clever new governance mechanisms (smart governance-practices) that are being developed and employed to improve the functioning of the partnerships.

The program is financed through the Smart Governance Research Fund of the Dutch Science Foundation (NWO) and has several co-financing organizations (NSOB, Rebel groep, Twijnstra Gudde, ResetManagement en Deltares). The program runs from 2015 till 2020.

projects.title: Flood Early Warning Systems in Bangladesh
projects.description: The project aims to improve the current Flood Early Warning System of Bangladesh by improving the quality (content) of the Early Warning Signal and the effectiveness of the process (organization) of the dissemination phase. In order to do a software application is being developed in combination with an institutional design for effective dissemination and this setup will be implemented and evaluated in the flooding season. Additionally to ensure the financial sustainability of the proposed system the project identifies alternative social business models for the exploitation and maintenance of it.

projects.title: Framework for Assessment of Alternative Procurement Strategies for flood protection infrastructure. The potential of innovative contracts for the New Flood Protection Program (nHWBP)
projects.description:
The main objective of the project is to develop a decision support tool for Water Boards that allows them to estimate the potential of early private sector involvement and innovative (integrated) contracts in achieving the efficiency gains envisioned by the New (National) Flood Protection Program (nHWBP in Dutch).
Activities performed: case study research of dike reinforcing projects in four water boards, quantification of the value added of early private sector involvement and innovative contracts by  carrying a Public Private Comparator (PPC) for these projects, integration of  technical expertise on Water Management and Delta Technology and project delivery and finance methods; in order to identify concrete projects with the highest potential, design of decision support tool and training of water boards on the use hereof.

profile_positions.description:
Research title: “Innovative Contracting Practices in the Road Sector. Cross-national lessons in dealing with opportunistic behaviour” 
Over the past fifteen to twenty years, the world has seen a proliferation of innovative approaches for the delivery and financing of public services, such as Public-Private- Partnerships (PPPs). Expectations in the road sector are high: more contract flexibility, more innovation, higher performance and consequently lower costs, while keeping up service levels on mobility, safety and the environment. But how successful have road authorities actually been in implementing such innovative arrangements?

This research answers the question by investigating how different national road administration authorities have implemented innovative arrangements and with what consequences. In addition, by developing and playing the serious game “Road Roles”, the introduction of innovative arrangements was simulated multiple times in various settings. 
Lessons are drawn for road authorities around the world that are considering to implement innovative financing and project delivery approaches. 

Developed and implemented case study research protocol, field research, and institutional and market analysis of the road sector in Finland, Netherlands, and Spain.
• Analysed technical and institutional dimensions of road procurement strategies and road reform.
• Analysed project cycle, contract structures, payment schemes, and project finance of large transport PPP projects.
• Developed “Road Roles” simulation game. Pioneered the use of experimental economics methods to study impact of contract incentives on cooperative behaviour.
• Developed community of practice on road innovative contracting.
